review_title: Excellent starter jobs or dual education/employment opportunity
job_title: Research Assistant in Stennis Space Center, MS
pros: An incredibly enjoyable working environment. In my experience, you will frequently get opportunities to be involved in a wide variety of projects, research, and free classes/seminars. Regardless of your actual job tasks, there will be calls for volunteers to help on strange, interesting, and sometimes just outright fun side projects. These can provide excellent learning experiences and a chance to pick up some highly desirable skills.
cons: No real opportunity for advancement without also pursuing a degree program. The hiring structure is definitely geared towards funneling people into higher education. It's a perfectly fine setup for a university, but you should understand that if you are being hired with a bachelors you are on a stepping-stone job, not a career path, and you won't be moving from that position. This isn't management's fault, either. It's just a feature of the university workplace. But it is something to keep in mind.

pros: Work life balance, work atmosphere

cons: The school is basically an extension of the main campus but they often forget that we exist down here. It's weird because it some aspects, resources are shared between here and the main campus but in other aspects, they don't share. I also feel like this place lacks culture and diversity in their staff. Additionally, when I was first hired, they made themselves seem like they value the work-life balance and that they're flexible on time and schedules but that actually varies by department.

review_title: Southern Miss isn't a place I would ever work again.
pros: If you need a job, there are jobs at USM.  Students are about average in terms of attitude and quality, although the Mississippi educational system does fail to prepare them adequately for a real university education.  If you're willing to suck up to administrators and do whatever they want you to do without question, then USM is a place you might consider.  If you're willing to put your morals and ethics in cold storage, then USM is a place you might consider.  If you're a game player, a schemer, a political animal, or anyone else who thinks teaching and doing research is stupid, then USM is a great university to work for.
cons: It's like a plantation.  Administrators are the overseers and faculty are slaves.  Don't expect merit to count for anything -- it's all about your seniority, who you're related to, and who you're doing favors for.  Having a national reputation means nothing at USM.  You can work to build up a strong national presence in your field's scholarship outlets and you will still be worth less to the administrators than someone who has never published one article but who has been there a long time.  USM is the 3rd school in the state, and administrators are perfectly willing not to rock any political boats if it means they get to keep their cushy jobs.

review_title: Dissatisfied due to bad experiences with a sociopath/bully boss, and the lack of checks and balances.
pros: Some programs and colleges have wonderful people that are talented, intelligent, and respectful.  The university has the potential to become larger and more well-known.
cons: The constant turnover of administrators and the retention of inbred (graduates of the school) faculty creates a poor environment for new ideas, progressive activities, and the retention of faculty from other institutions.  The lack of checks and balances for the people put in charge of programs, schools, and departments has allowed some people to remain in positions that they are unqualified to hold, allowing those unqualified persons to intimidate non-tenured faculty, staff, and even students without penalty.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Hattiesburg, MS
pros:
Some very good faculty members who will mentor you
The job comes with free tuition and offers insurance for $80 a month
They keep your hours you actually work low so you can still excel in coursework
You are treated like a member of the department
cons:
They pay really is not enough to live on--much less buy your books. $1,000 a month
90 percent chance you will grade for HIS exams the entire time you are employed
Only a couple of students will get to work during the summer 
They do not think they owe GTAs any extra appreciation to compensate for a non-livable wage

review_title: Biology department at USM is awesome
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Hattiesburg, MS
pros: Biology department at USM is awesome. Particularly MS-INBRE is god's gift  for Biology department. We have almost all the equipments for molecular and biochemical work, and equipments are being purchased continuously. I am sure, in the coming years, it will be even better and competitive place to work for.
cons: University management should pay attention towards student's employment after graduation. They should establish a very strong campus placement cell. It is required for the campus placement cell to figure out the skill requirements (along with degree) for the companies for jobs, and make the respective departments to include them in the curriculum. They should organize regular workshops to let students know the skill requirements for jobs. It is lot of work...but more than worth for USM.

review_title: Great environment, great people, but broke as a joke. A good starting point.
pros: Beautiful campus, 90 min away from everything (New Orleans, Gulfport, Tuscaloosa, Pensacola is close too.)  Great people, very friendly, cheap cost of living.
cons: The university is bankrupt, there is no money anywhere in the city.  That doesn't make the city bad or a bad place to live or anything along those lines.  The University is just struggling on the financial side of things.

review_title: Perfect job for a student who would like some extra cash.
pros: Great hours, great pay, perfect way to study and make financial gain simultaneously. The job has little responsibility, and depending on the supervisor, it can be a fun and sociable experience.
cons: It's a customer service job, and sometimes a supervisor will treat you with little respect. Also, make sure that you can make the hours that you schedule in advance, and try to trade shifts early. It is only part-time, so the max you can work is 20 hours.

review_title: Instructor in the College of Business
job_title: Professor of Practice in Hattiesburg, MS
pros:
The faculty and staff in the College of Business are friendly and helpful. I was in the Department of Finance Real Estate and Business Law. All the people I worked with were really nice.
I enjoy teaching and got great satisfaction from seeing students learn.
cons: One of the difficulties I faced was the students who were unprepared for college work. Some students had a poor understanding of basic arithmetic and financial concepts. Teaching these students was a challenge because they tried to learn by rote instead of understanding concepts.

pros:
Town is nice - good pubic schools for kids, inexpensive housing, short commute
a scattering of good students
cons:
pay scale is low even compared to other Mississippi Universities
basically open admissions results in poor, unmotivated, discouraging classes
benefits package is terrible
few written rules + lots of administrators with turf to protect = very negative atmosphere
lots of nepotism - well connected locals ignore the rules
nasty, political and punitive tenure process ( I got mine working 100 hours a week... good luck)

job_title: Anonymous Employee in West Hattiesburg, MS
pros: Laid back atmosphere, campus amenities, park-like setting.
cons: You have to pay to park.  Medical benefits are sub-par.  Pay is 10-20% lower compared to other state institutions of higher learning.  No room for advancement, as in, HR does not have a system for giving raises.  The only "advancement" is to wait for another job opening that pays more and apply to it.

job_title: Graduate Student in Stennis Space Center, MS
pros: Work with some great research scientists.  The Dept. of Marine Science has some of the top researchers in the field.  Also, graduate research assistants make over $20k per year plus tuition is waived and you get health insurance.
cons: You really need to stay on top of your adviser.  The DMS students need to have more interaction with main campus.  It is a bit isolated at SSC.

review_title: Perks of a University job are hard to make up for such low pay
pros:
Free classes and other educational perks.
Educated co-workers.
Time off
cons:
Pay is low by industry standards.
Many middle- and upper-management have become complacent, and seem generally incompetent to implement and manage.  Management by fear in some instances.

pros: This position pays your tuition and offers a stipend. The fact that departments rely heavily on graduate assistants to help professors deal with increasing class sizes offers a lot of job security.
cons: Low stipend amount hovers just around subsistence wages. Professional opportunities and chances to make extra money are not advertised and often given to favorites. Health insurance covers traumatic care, but it is basically a discount program for everything else. Department cultures vary, but Graduate Assistants are often treated like children rather than junior members of the academy. There are a lot of unwritten rules about "volunteer" service.

review_title: All the perks of a university job
pros:
Free classes and other educational perks.
Educated co-workers.
Merit is generally rewarded
Campus has village-within-a-city atmosphere
cons:
Pay is low by industry standards.
Many IT middle- and upper-management have become complacent, and seem generally incompetent to implement and manage complex projects. The department has a history of bungled launches and unsatisfactory services. Everyone on campus seems to have a poor opinion of the IT department.

review_title: Excellent educational experience for forensic science
job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Hattiesburg, MS
pros: The University of Southern Mississippi boasts a well-connected and knowledgeable School of Criminal Justice and Forensic Science unit. The professors have career experience in their respective fields, and commensurate teaching experience. The department as a whole carries compassion for all of their students, and encourages each student to make the most of their education and career.
cons: Graduate student salaries are understandably meager, but the camaraderie of the program and interactions with the faculty seem well worth the lower pay.

job_title: Graduate Assistant in Long Beach, MS
pros: There are so many pros!  It was a wonderful environment and a great experience.  It added value to the degree that I was working toward because it allowed me to interface with the professors more than just in class and I was able to tutor other students further cementing my own understanding of the material.  I also gained valuable experience in a wide variety of settings as various opportunities presented themselves.
cons: The only con that I can think of is that the experience had to end.

review_title: The work environment is so friendly and evryone are so coperative to one another.Great mentors to work in research labor

cons: Remains too busy  in work. So have to sometimes miss my time to my family and friends.

review_title: Low pay, but low cost of living
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Hattiesburg, MS
pros: The job duties aren't all that bad if you like working with undergraduates. Many students come unprepared for college, so they rely on the a lot of tutoring, understanding, and positive reinforcement rise up to their full potential. Some grad assistants have a bad attitude about this, but it can be fulfilling work.
cons: Low pay and poor benefits. Don't get sick while you're working here. Pay stinks, but the cost of living is low.

review_title: USM Gulf Coast  is a beautiful campus on the Missississippi Gulf Coast.

cons: Big divide between coast campus and the main campus in Hattiesburg.  Not enough resources dedicated to this growing campus on the coast compared to Hattiesburg.

pros: Great co workers with an opportunity to work at the heart of the university. There was flexible scheduling and decent pay. You get to learn the ins and outs of student organizations and some university operations. Room for advancement if interested and if you show initiative.
cons: This was a work study position, but I was reprimanded for studying while on the job.

review_title: A good place to work, but some major compensation flaws.

cons: No real admissions policy, a great cross section of students, very diverse, but some very low performing students as well. Lots of duties piled on faculty, not enough time to do research. Very poor compensation for faculty and staff, no raises in years.

cons: Plenty of dead weight coworkers.  MS has been cutting its education budget for decades to make room in the budget for idiotic corporate tax cuts, so enjoy constant penny-pinching and fear for your job.

review_title: Need to be more aware of industry trends

cons: Sometimes employees are too relaxed which can make their behavior seem less than professional at times.  Also, pay could be better.

review_title: This university is good as long as you want to stay in academia in your career afterward

cons: Departments except polymer science has more or less no industry connection. So, it is hard to network with industry people. Library do not have subscriptions to many upper tier journals.
